Curt Sampson wrote:

> I'm not trying to imply that you're too lazy to solve the problem. 

OK. You're using "kludge" in the clinical sense. The word has emotional 
overtones for me, so that's what I reacted to. I understand better now 
what you meant, and no harm done.

 > I kludge things all the time because the
> downside of the kludge is less than the cost to "do it right."

I think this is a case where you don't know yet how to "do it right". I 
suggest filtering the test results until you have a few different 
instances of such dependencies, from which you can get a better sense of 
how you'd "do it right". That's what I would do.

Take care.
